::: {.notes}
Radiocarbon dates are among the most common and widely shared archaeological data across regional specificities. Accompanied by archaeological contexts, these dates are often utilized to develop large-scale models of human activities and to categorize cultural groups over time and space. The NeoNet project brings together several archaeologists from different geographic areas, focusing on the transition between the last hunter-gatherers and the early farmers. As part of this project, we have compiled and curated a substantial dataset of radiocarbon dates, which can be accessed through an R Shiny online app, the NeoNet app. Today, we want to explain how our method tackles research questions and follows the FAIR principles.
:::

## {data-background-iframe="http://shinyserver.cfs.unipi.it:3838/C14dev" background-interactive="true"}

::: {.notes}
NeoNet app is an opensource R Shiny interactive web app which facilitates their study by providing selection tools for spatial information, chronology, and date accuracy. The map interface offers a mobile and multi-scalar window to study the dynamic of last hunter-gathers / early farmers frontiers <br>
NB: prepare the map: Global view / clustered / ortho ; Explode cluster / ungroup / OSM
:::


## {}

<div class="img">
![](img/watersheds-ortho.png){width="1100"}
</div>

::: {.notes}
To facilitate dataset curation, it has been divided into two parts based on river basins: NeoNet Atl, focusing on the Atlantic region (in blue), and NeoNet Med, dedicated to the North Central-Western Mediterranean Basin (in red). The decision to partition by river basins is grounded in two primary considerations: it allows for the systematic breakdown, or hierarchical decomposition, of river basins into interconnected and nested components; watersheds are crucial as spatial analysis units, facilitating mathematical modeling that incorporates key concepts such as catchment area, thalweg (shortest path), and natural boundaries.
:::

## {}

The NeoNet Atl dataset

```{r}
library(dplyr)
library(DT)
neonet_med <- "https://digitallib.unipi.it/fedora/objects/mag:2627/datastreams/MMb1a4a927461fdd822e923821b8d92371/content"
df.c14 <- read.csv2(neonet_med, sep = "\t", encoding = "UTF-8")
font.size <- "8pt"
df.c14[,!names(df.c14) %in% c("tpq", "taq")] %>% 
  DT::datatable(
    width = "100%",
    rownames = FALSE,
    options=list(
      lengthMenu = list(c(10, 50, -1), 
                        c('10', '50', 'All')),
      paging = T,
      initComplete = htmlwidgets::JS(
        "function(settings, json) {",
        paste0("$(this.api().table().container()).css({'font-size': '", font.size, "'});"),
        "}")
    ) 
  )
```


::: {.notes}
*Kervouric*. These datasets have been limited to essential radiocarbon date information: the date, period, location, archaeological unit, type of material dated, and bibliographical references. NeoNet Atl and Med include approximately 4,000 radiocarbon dates from around 3,000 distinct archaeological layers, along with about 800 sites mentioned in bibliographical references. These dates and archaeological contexts are backed by roughly 600 different bibliographical sources.
:::

## {}

<div class="img">
![](img/donzere-gis.png){width="1000"}
</div>
<div class="captiontext">Koppen Climate Classification[^1].
</div>


::: {.notes}
For instance, the Défilé de Donzère is a narrow pass in the Rhone valley, extending from North to South, located between the Alps in the east and the Massif Central in the west. In this area, the southern part has a Mediterranean climate (`Csa` - Temperate, dry and hot summer), while the northern part experiences a continental climate (`Cfb` - Temperate, no dry season, warm summer). It is worth to note also that the Rhone river acted like a cultural frontier during the Late Neolithic.
:::

::: {.notes}
An user create a selection window around the Défilé, specifically choosing dates from the Late Mesolithic (LM) and Early Neolithic (EN) periods, with a standard deviation (SD) of less than 130. Applying these filters, the dataset will contain 70 sites and 353 dates. These dates can be calibrated on the fly by selecting one of them and accessing the calib (calibration) panel.
:::

<div class="img"><center>

::: {.notes}
Dates can be aggregated and seriated by periods (shown here), sites and periods, archaeological layer (PhaseCode), or plotted individually. However, a large number of dates will overwhelm the R Shiny server and may result in an error in this panel. This is one of the limitations of R for managing big data.
:::

## Conclusion

![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/neonet/master/doc/img/panel_map_export_todo.png){width="500" style='horizontal-align: middle;'}

</center>

* App and dataset of 14C dates for the **Mesolithic / Neolithic transition** in **South-Central and South-Western Europe**
* Open Data, Open Source, Open Access ➡️ **Open Science**
* Scalable, incrementable, reusable, analyzable ➡️ **Reproducibility**

::: {.notes}
* Neonet offers an app and curated datasets of radiocarbon dates for the Mesolithic / Neolithic transition, currently in South-Central and South-Western Europe
* The dataset is OD, the app and management functions are OSrc and OA. Compliant with OSci
* The app allows a multiscalar approach, the partition in river basins makes it easily incrementable, being compliant with OS makes also the framework reusable, and side functions make easier the analysis. These features make, potentially, radiocarbon analysis mostly reproductible. 
:::

## Perspectives

<center>

![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/neonet/master/doc/img/panel_map_export_todo.png){width="500" style='horizontal-align: middle;'}

</center>

* Enhancing data and data re-usability
* Extension of the dataset to other river basins
* Build sites' Harris matrices and run Bayesian with this *prior* information

::: {.notes}
Perspectives are many:

* We need IT development to allow to study and contrast different geographical windows at the same time (here at the South and the North of the Defile)
* FAIRability can still be improved
* Watersheds partition is highly modular (hierarchical decomposition) and interactivity offer a great mean for reproductibility and robust assumptions.
* We would like to construct the Harris matrices of different site and run Bayesian statistics to better the modeling
:::
